to take the crystal ball by force. Ream Eyso flew through the air 
in search of Moni Mekhala, propelled on by a jealous rage. On his way, he encountered Vorachhun 
and attacked him, knowing that the righteous prince would
never allow him to steal the crystal. The demon gained the upper hand 
in the heat of battle, and hurled Vorachhun 
against the side of a mountain. Sure of Vorachhun’s death, Ream Eyso continued his search
until he finally found Moni Mekhala. He demanded that she 
and her friends either submit to him, the most brilliant of Lok Ta’s students 
and rightful master of the crystal ball, or die like Vorachhun. Mekhala, without fear, 
refused and flew off into the clouds, hoping to draw the demon away
from her friends. Ream Eyso took the bait, ripping through
nimbus after nimbus in his crazed pursuit. Once far enough away, 
Mekhala confronted her pursuer. Ream Eyso made one last demand 
but the goddess remained unfazed. Enraged, he began 
to swing his diamond axe. Before he could hurl the weapon,
Mekhala threw her crystal into the air. As it climbed the height of the sky, it emitted powerful flashes 
of lightning that blinded the demon. Ream Eyso let his axe loose 
in wild desperation. As the weapon flew through the air 
it cut through clouds, creating deep, rolling peals of thunder. And when the lightning and thunder mixed, precious seeds 
of water fell from heaven: rain. Mekhala drew close to Ream Eyso, 
now blind and impotent without his axe. She pondered what
she should do to the murderer. Remembering the kindness 
and love of her teacher, Moni Mekhala chose compassion 
and flew into the sky. Shortly later, Ream Eyso regained his 
strength, found his axe, and followed her. Thunder, lightning, and rain continued 
to dance across the earth. Some drops fell on Vorachhun
and revived him, his skin golden like 
a rice field ready for harvest. Grabbing his magic dagger, he flew into the sky in search 
of Ream Eyso and Moni Mekhala.

Options: A. He was bored, B. He liked contests, C. He wanted to have a fair way to give his most deserving student the prize, D. He was thirsty
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Once, a long time ago, there was a powerful hermit 
named Lok Ta Moni Eysei. He had three promising students: Moni Mekhala, 
the brilliant goddess of the seas, Vorachhun, the princely
manifestation of the earth, and Ream Eyso, a demon whose 
heart burned with passionate fire. Lok Ta wished to bestow a gift 
upon his most deserving student. To determine which of the three that was,
he announced a contest: whoever first brought back 
a glass full of morning dew would be master of this mysterious gift. When dusk came, Vorachhun 
and Ream Eyso ventured into the forest. They left not one leaf 
or blade of grass untouched, impatiently shaking 
the precious fluid into their glasses. When they returned to the hermit’s hut, they found Moni Mekhala sitting patiently 
with a full glass of morning dew. She had left her shawl out overnight and won the contest by simply
wringing out the fabric over her glass. Proud of all his students, 
and loving them like his own children, Lok Ta surprised all three with gifts. He turned the dew Ream Eyso 
collected into a diamond axe, Vorachhun’s into a magic dagger, and Moni Mekhala’s into a crystal ball 
unlike anything ever seen. Soon Ream Eyso grew covetous 
and decided he must have Mekhala’s prize. He and Vorachhun tried to woo the goddess
so they could get the precious gem. But after she rejected their advances 
and flew off, Ream Eyso resolved 
to take the crystal ball by force. Ream Eyso flew through the air 
in search of Moni Mekhala, propelled on by a jealous rage. On his way, he encountered Vorachhun 
and attacked him, knowing that the righteous prince would
never allow him to steal the crystal. The demon gained the upper hand 
in the heat of battle, and hurled Vorachhun 
against the side of a mountain. Sure of Vorachhun’s death, Ream Eyso continued his search
until he finally found Moni Mekhala. He demanded that she 
and her friends either submit to him, the most brilliant of Lok Ta’s students 
and rightful master of the crystal ball, or die like Vorachhun. Mekhala, without fear, 
refused and flew off into the clouds, hoping to draw the demon away
from her friends. Ream Eyso took the bait, ripping through
nimbus after nimbus in his crazed pursuit. Once far enough away, 
Mekhala confronted her pursuer. Ream Eyso made one last demand 
but the goddess remained unfazed. Enraged, he began 
to swing his diamond axe. Before he could hurl the weapon,
Mekhala threw her crystal into the air. As it climbed the height of the sky, it emitted powerful flashes 
of lightning that blinded the demon. Ream Eyso let his axe loose 
in wild desperation. As the weapon flew through the air 
it cut through clouds, creating deep, rolling peals of thunder. And when the lightning and thunder mixed, precious seeds 
of water fell from heaven: rain. Mekhala drew close to Ream Eyso, 
now blind and impotent without his axe. She pondered what
she should do to the murderer. Remembering the kindness 
and love of her teacher, Moni Mekhala chose compassion 
and flew into the sky. Shortly later, Ream Eyso regained his 
strength, found his axe, and followed her. Thunder, lightning, and rain continued 
to dance across the earth. Some drops fell on Vorachhun
and revived him, his skin golden like 
a rice field ready for harvest. Grabbing his magic dagger, he flew into the sky in search 
of Ream Eyso and Moni Mekhala.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How did Moni Mekhala win the contest?
Options: A. By creating a clever plan and strategy, B. By being innovative, C. By leaving her shawl out overnight and wringing out the dew it soaked, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the contest announced by Lok Ta Moni Eysei to determine which of his three students was the most deserving? Options: A. Whoever could collect the most leaves in the forest, B. Whoever first brought back a glass full of morning dew, C. Whoever could shake the most branches in the forest, D. Whoever could fly the highest in the sky Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following students won the contest by simply wringing out their shawl over a glass? Options: A. Moni Mekhala, B. Vorachhun, C. Ream Eyso, D. Lok Ta Moni Eysei Correct Option: A
Question 3: What gift did Lok Ta Moni Eysei give to Moni Mekhala for winning the contest? Options: A. A diamond axe, B. A magic dagger, C. A crystal ball unlike anything ever seen, D. A glass of morning dew Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why did Ream Eyso try to woo Moni Mekhala? Options: A. He wanted to be friends with her, B. He wanted to get the crystal ball, C. He wanted to fly with her, D. He wanted to eat with her Correct Option: B
Question 5: What happened to Vorachhun when Ream Eyso attacked him? Options: A. He was killed, B. He was hurled against the side of a mountain, C. He was not affected, D. He was turned into a demon Correct Option: B
Question 6: What did Moni Mekhala do to Ream Eyso when he demanded that she and her friends submit to him? Options: A. She refused and flew off into the clouds, B. She agreed and submitted to him, C. She attacked him with her crystal ball, D. She hid in the forest Correct Option: A
Question 7: What happened to Ream Eyso when Moni Mekhala threw her crystal ball into the air? Options: A. He was blinded by powerful flashes of lightning, B. He was killed by the crystal ball, C. He was unaffected, D. He was turned into a demon Correct Option: A
Question 8: What did Moni Mekhala choose to do to Ream Eyso after he was blinded and impotent? Options: A. She killed him, B. She left him to die, C. She chose compassion and flew into the sky, D. She attacked him with her crystal ball Correct Option: C
Question 9: What happened to Vorachhun when he was revived by the rain? Options: A. He was turned into a demon, B. He was killed, C. He was healed and regained his strength, D. He was unaffected Correct Option: C
Question 10: What did Vorachhun do after he was revived by the rain? Options: A. He attacked Moni Mekhala, B. He flew into the sky in search of Ream Eyso and Moni Mekhala, C. He hid in the forest, D. He went back to Lok Ta Moni Eysei Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Although Question 2 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question wording and options, it shares the same intent and content. Both questions focus on how Moni Mekhala won the contest, and the correct option in Question 2 (A. Moni Mekhala) corresponds to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. By leaving her shawl out overnight and wringing out the dew it soaked, which is a description of Moni Mekhala's actions).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Once, a long time ago, there was a powerful hermit 
named Lok Ta Moni Eysei. He had three promising students: Moni Mekhala, 
the brilliant goddess of the seas, Vorachhun, the princely
manifestation of the earth, and Ream Eyso, a demon whose 
heart burned with passionate fire. Lok Ta wished to bestow a gift 
upon his most deserving student. To determine which of the three that was,
he announced a contest: whoever first brought back 
a glass full of morning dew would be master of this mysterious gift. When dusk came, Vorachhun 
and Ream Eyso ventured into the forest. They left not one leaf 
or blade of grass untouched, impatiently shaking 
the precious fluid into their glasses. When they returned to the hermit’s hut, they found Moni Mekhala sitting patiently 
with a full glass of morning dew. She had left her shawl out overnight and won the contest by simply
wringing out the fabric over her glass. Proud of all his students, 
and loving them like his own children, Lok Ta surprised all three with gifts. He turned the dew Ream Eyso 
collected into a diamond axe, Vorachhun’s into a magic dagger, and Moni Mekhala’s into a crystal ball 
unlike anything ever seen. Soon Ream Eyso grew covetous 
and decided he must have Mekhala’s prize. He and Vorachhun tried to woo the goddess
so they could get the precious gem. But after she rejected their advances 
and flew off, Ream Eyso resolved 
to take the crystal ball by force. Ream Eyso flew through the air 
in search of Moni Mekhala, propelled on by a jealous rage. On his way, he encountered Vorachhun 
and attacked him, knowing that the righteous prince would
never allow him to steal the crystal. The demon gained the upper hand 
in the heat of battle, and hurled Vorachhun 
against the side of a mountain. Sure of Vorachhun’s death, Ream Eyso continued his search
until he finally found Moni Mekhala. He demanded that she 
and her friends either submit to him, the most brilliant of Lok Ta’s students 
and rightful master of the crystal ball, or die like Vorachhun. Mekhala, without fear, 
refused and flew off into the clouds, hoping to draw the demon away
from her friends. Ream Eyso took the bait, ripping through
nimbus after nimbus in his crazed pursuit. Once far enough away, 
Mekhala confronted her pursuer. Ream Eyso made one last demand 
but the goddess remained unfazed. Enraged, he began 
to swing his diamond axe. Before he could hurl the weapon,
Mekhala threw her crystal into the air. As it climbed the height of the sky, it emitted powerful flashes 
of lightning that blinded the demon. Ream Eyso let his axe loose 
in wild desperation. As the weapon flew through the air 
it cut through clouds, creating deep, rolling peals of thunder. And when the lightning and thunder mixed, precious seeds 
of water fell from heaven: rain. Mekhala drew close to Ream Eyso, 
now blind and impotent without his axe. She pondered what
she should do to the murderer. Remembering the kindness 
and love of her teacher, Moni Mekhala chose compassion 
and flew into the sky. Shortly later, Ream Eyso regained his 
strength, found his axe, and followed her. Thunder, lightning, and rain continued 
to dance across the earth. Some drops fell on Vorachhun
and revived him, his skin golden like 
a rice field ready for harvest. Grabbing his magic dagger, he flew into the sky in search 
of Ream Eyso and Moni Mekhala.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why did Ream Eyso want Moni Mekhala’s crystal ball?
Options: A. He was greedy, B. He was too proud and thought he was the best, C. He lacked mudita, the Buddhist concept of being happy for the good fortunes and success of others, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 7: What happened to Ream Eyso when Moni Mekhala threw her crystal ball into the air? Options: A. He was blinded by powerful flashes of lightning, B. He was killed by the crystal ball, C. He was unaffected, D. He was turned into a demon Correct Option: A
Question 8: What did Moni Mekhala choose to do to Ream Eyso after he was blinded and impotent? Options: A. She killed him, B. She left him to die, C. She chose compassion and flew into the sky, D. She attacked him with her crystal ball Correct Option: C
Question 9: What happened to Vorachhun when he was revived by the rain? Options: A. He was turned into a demon, B. He was killed, C. He was healed and regained his strength, D. He was unaffected Correct Option: C
Question 10: What did Vorachhun do after he was revived by the rain? Options: A. He attacked Moni Mekhala, B. He flew into the sky in search of Ream Eyso and Moni Mekhala, C. He hid in the forest, D. He went back to Lok Ta Moni Eysei Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

Although Question 4 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options, it is the closest match among the provided generated MCQs. Question 4 addresses Ream Eyso's motivations for trying to woo Moni Mekhala, which is related to his desire for the crystal ball. However, it does not capture the full intent of the ground truth MCQ, which asks why Ream Eyso wanted Moni Mekhala's crystal ball and provides options that include greed, pride, and lack of mudita.

named Lok Ta Moni Eysei. He had three promising students: Moni Mekhala, 
the brilliant goddess of the seas, Vorachhun, the princely
manifestation of the earth, and Ream Eyso, a demon whose

upon his most deserving student. To determine which of the three that was,

a glass full of morning dew would be master of this mysterious gift. When dusk came, Vorachhun 
and Ream Eyso ventured into the forest. They left not one leaf 
or blade of grass untouched, impatiently shaking 
the precious fluid into their glasses. When they returned to the hermit’s hut, they found Moni Mekhala sitting patiently 
with a full glass of morning dew. She had left her shawl out overnight and won the contest by simply
wringing out the fabric over her glass. Proud of all his students, 
and loving them like his own children, Lok Ta surprised all three with gifts. He turned the dew Ream Eyso 
collected into a diamond axe, Vorachhun’s into a magic dagger, and Moni Mekhala’s into a crystal ball 
unlike anything ever seen. Soon Ream Eyso grew covetous 
and decided he must have Mekhala’s prize. He and Vorachhun tried to woo the goddess

in the heat of battle, and hurled Vorachhun

until he finally found Moni Mekhala. He demanded that she

and rightful master of the crystal ball, or die like Vorachhun. Mekhala, without fear, 
refused and flew off into the clouds, hoping to draw the demon away
from her friends. Ream Eyso took the bait, ripping through
nimbus after nimbus in his crazed pursuit. Once far enough away, 
Mekhala confronted her pursuer. Ream Eyso made one last demand 
but the goddess remained unfazed. Enraged, he began 
to swing his diamond axe. Before he could hurl the weapon,
Mekhala threw her crystal into the air. As it climbed the height of the sky, it emitted powerful flashes 
of lightning that blinded the demon. Ream Eyso let his axe loose 
in wild desperation. As the weapon flew through the air 
it cut through clouds, creating deep, rolling peals of thunder. And when the lightning and thunder mixed, precious seeds 
of water fell from heaven: rain. Mekhala drew close to Ream Eyso, 
now blind and impotent without his axe. She pondered what
she should do to the murderer. Remembering the kindness 
and love of her teacher, Moni Mekhala chose compassion 
and flew into the sky. Shortly later, Ream Eyso regained his 
strength, found his axe, and followed her. Thunder, lightning, and rain continued 
to dance across the earth. Some drops fell on Vorachhun
and revived him, his skin golden like 
a rice field ready for harvest. Grabbing his magic dagger, he flew into the sky in search 
of Ream Eyso and Moni Mekhala.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to this Khmer myth, what does the union of lightning and thunder create?
Options: A. Rain, B. Earth, C. Cotton candy, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Most history books will tell you the Roman
Empire fell in the fifth century CE. But this would’ve come as a great surprise
to the millions of people who lived in the Roman Empire up
through the Middle Ages. This medieval Roman Empire, which we usually refer 
to today as the Byzantine Empire, began in 330 CE. That’s when Constantine,
the first Christian emperor, moved the capital of the Roman Empire 
to a new city called Constantinople, which he founded on the site of the
ancient Greek city Byzantion. When the Visigoths sacked Rome in 410 and the Empire’s western provinces 
were conquered by barbarians, Constantine’s Eastern capital remained 
the seat of the Roman emperors. There, generations of emperors ruled 
for the next 11 centuries. Sharing continuity with 
the classical Roman Empire gave the Byzantine empire a technological
and artistic advantage over its neighbors, whom Byzantines considered barbarians. In the ninth century, 
visitors from beyond the frontier were astonished 
at the graceful stone arches and domes of the imperial palace in Constantinople. A pair of golden lions flanked 
the imperial throne. A hidden organ would make the lions 
roar as guests fell on their knees. Golden birds
sung from a nearby golden tree. Medieval Roman engineers 
even used hydraulic engines to raise the imperial throne 
high into the air. Other inherited aspects 
of ancient Roman culture could be seen in emperors’ clothing, from traditional military garb to togas, and in the courts, which continued to use Roman law. Working-class Byzantines would’ve also 
had similar lives to their Ancient Roman counterparts; many farmed or plied a specific trade, such as ceramics, leatherworking, fishing, weaving, or manufacturing silk. But, of course, the Byzantine Empire didn’t just rest 
on the laurels of Ancient Rome. Their artists innovated, creating vast 
mosaics and ornate marble carvings. Their architects constructed
numerous churches, one of which, called Hagia Sophia, had a dome so high it was said to be
hanging on a chain from heaven. The Empire was also home to great
intellectuals such as Anna Komnene. As imperial princess in the 12th century, Anna dedicated her life 
to philosophy and history. Her account of her father’s reign
is historians’ foremost source for Byzantine political history 
at the time of the first crusade. Another scholar, Leo the Mathematician, invented a system of beacons that ran the
width of the empire— what’s now Greece and Turkey. Stretching more than 700 kilometers, this system allowed the edge of the Empire
to warn the emperor of invading armies within one hour
of sighting them at the border. But their advances couldn’t 
protect the Empire forever. In 1203, an army of French 
and Venetian Crusaders made a deal with a man 
named Alexios Angelos. Alexios was the son of a deposed emperor, and promised the crusaders vast riches and support to help him retake 
the throne from his uncle. Alexios succeeded, but after a year, the population rebelled and Alexios 
himself was deposed and killed. So Alexios’s unpaid army turned 
their aggression on Constantinople. They lit massive fires, which destroyed countless works of ancient
and medieval art and literature, leaving about one-third 
of the population homeless. The city was reclaimed 50 years later 
by the Roman Emperor Michael Palaiologos, but his restored Empire never regained
all the territory the Crusaders had conquered. Finally, in 1453, Ottoman Emperor Mehmed
the Conqueror captured Constantinople, bringing a conclusive end 
to the Roman Empire. Despite the Ottoman conquest, many Greek-speaking inhabitants 
of the Eastern Mediterranean continued to call themselves Romans 
until the early 21st century. In fact, it wasn’t until the Renaissance that the term “Byzantine Empire” 
was first used. For Western Europeans, the Renaissance was about 
reconnecting with the wisdom of antiquity. And since the existence of a
medieval Roman Empire suggested there were Europeans 
who’d never lost touch with antiquity, Western Europeans wanted to draw 
clear lines between the ages. To better distinguish the classical, 
Latin-speaking, pagan Roman Empire from the medieval, 
Greek-speaking, Christian Roman Empire, scholars renamed 
the latter group Byzantines. And thus, 100 years after it had
fallen, the Byzantine Empire was born.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When did the Byzantine Empire begin?
Options: A. 125 CE, B. 130 CE, C. 350 CE, D. 535 CE
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year did Constantine move the capital of the Roman Empire to a new city called Constantinople? Options: A. 300 CE, B. 330 CE, C. 410 CE, D. 1453 CE Correct Option: B
Question 2: What historical period is the Byzantine Empire known to have been in continuity with? Options: A. Ancient Greek, B. Ancient Roman, C. Medieval European, D. Modern Greek Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the primary reason for the Byzantine Empire's technological and artistic advantage over its neighbors? Options: A. Innovative use of iron and steel, B. Adoption of new architectural styles, C. Continuity with ancient Roman culture, D. Military conquests Correct Option: C
Question 4: Who was the imperial princess who dedicated her life to philosophy and wrote a historical account of her father's reign? Options: A. Anna Komnene, B. Leo the Mathematician, C. Alexios Angelos, D. Michael Palaiologos Correct Option: A
Question 5: Who invented the Byzantine Empire's system of beacons that stretched over 700 kilometers? Options: A. Anna Komnene, B. Leo the Mathematician, C. Alexios Angelos, D. Michael Palaiologos Correct Option: B
Question 6: In 1203, an army of French and Venetian Crusaders made a deal with which man to help him retake the throne from his uncle? Options: A. Alexios Angelos, B. Michael Palaiologos, C. Mehmed the Conqueror, D. Leo the Mathematician Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the name of the church in Constantinople that had a dome so high it was said to be hanging on a chain from heaven? Options: A. Hagia Sophia, B. Byzantine Cathedral, C. Roman Church, D. Imperial Palace Correct Option: A
Question 8: Who conquered Constantinople in 1453, bringing an end to the Roman Empire? Options: A. Mehmed the Conqueror, B. Alexios Angelos, C. Michael Palaiologos, D. Leo the Mathematician Correct Option: A
Question 9: What term was used to describe the Byzantine Empire in Western Europe during the Renaissance? Options: A. Byzantine Empire, B. Eastern Roman Empire, C. Medieval Roman Empire, D. Roman Empire Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why did Western Europeans rename the medieval Roman Empire as the Byzantine Empire during the Renaissance? Options: A. To emphasize its connection to ancient Rome, B. To distinguish it from the classical Roman Empire, C. To highlight its Greek-speaking culture, D. To conceal its Christian heritage Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question asks about the year Constantine moved the capital of the Roman Empire to Constantinople, which is essentially when the Byzantine Empire began. The options and content of this question align with the ground truth MCQ, making it the most similar.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Most history books will tell you the Roman
Empire fell in the fifth century CE. But this would’ve come as a great surprise
to the millions of people who lived in the Roman Empire up
through the Middle Ages. This medieval Roman Empire, which we usually refer 
to today as the Byzantine Empire, began in 330 CE. That’s when Constantine,

to a new city called Constantinople, which he founded on the site of the

the seat of the Roman emperors. There, generations of emperors ruled

the classical Roman Empire gave the Byzantine empire a technological
and artistic advantage over its neighbors, whom Byzantines considered barbarians. In the ninth century,

at the graceful stone arches and domes of the imperial palace in Constantinople. A pair of golden lions flanked

sung from a nearby golden tree. Medieval Roman engineers

high into the air. Other inherited aspects

had similar lives to their Ancient Roman counterparts; many farmed or plied a specific trade, such as ceramics, leatherworking, fishing, weaving, or manufacturing silk. But, of course, the Byzantine Empire didn’t just rest 
on the laurels of Ancient Rome. Their artists innovated, creating vast 
mosaics and ornate marble carvings. Their architects constructed
numerous churches, one of which, called Hagia Sophia, had a dome so high it was said to be
hanging on a chain from heaven. The Empire was also home to great
intellectuals such as Anna Komnene. As imperial princess in the 12th century, Anna dedicated her life 
to philosophy and history. Her account of her father’s reign
is historians’ foremost source for Byzantine political history 
at the time of the first crusade. Another scholar, Leo the Mathematician, invented a system of beacons that ran the
width of the empire— what’s now Greece and Turkey. Stretching more than 700 kilometers, this system allowed the edge of the Empire
to warn the emperor of invading armies within one hour
of sighting them at the border. But their advances couldn’t 
protect the Empire forever. In 1203, an army of French 
and Venetian Crusaders made a deal with a man 
named Alexios Angelos. Alexios was the son of a deposed emperor, and promised the crusaders vast riches and support to help him retake 
the throne from his uncle. Alexios succeeded, but after a year, the population rebelled and Alexios 
himself was deposed and killed. So Alexios’s unpaid army turned 
their aggression on Constantinople. They lit massive fires, which destroyed countless works of ancient
and medieval art and literature, leaving about one-third 
of the population homeless. The city was reclaimed 50 years later 
by the Roman Emperor Michael Palaiologos, but his restored Empire never regained
all the territory the Crusaders had conquered. Finally, in 1453, Ottoman Emperor Mehmed
the Conqueror captured Constantinople, bringing a conclusive end 
to the Roman Empire. Despite the Ottoman conquest, many Greek-speaking inhabitants 
of the Eastern Mediterranean continued to call themselves Romans 
until the early 21st century. In fact, it wasn’t until the Renaissance that the term “Byzantine Empire” 
was first used. For Western Europeans, the Renaissance was about 
reconnecting with the wisdom of antiquity. And since the existence of a
medieval Roman Empire suggested there were Europeans 
who’d never lost touch with antiquity, Western Europeans wanted to draw 
clear lines between the ages. To better distinguish the classical, 
Latin-speaking, pagan Roman Empire from the medieval, 
Greek-speaking, Christian Roman Empire, scholars renamed 
the latter group Byzantines. And thus, 100 years after it had
fallen, the Byzantine Empire was born.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Whose historical work became the foremost source for Byzantine political history during the First Crusade?
Options: A. Anna Komnene, B. Gerda Lerner, C. Anyte of Tegea, D. Cleopatra
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Most history books will tell you the Roman
Empire fell in the fifth century CE. But this would’ve come as a great surprise
to the millions of people who lived in the Roman Empire up
through the Middle Ages. This medieval Roman Empire, which we usually refer 
to today as the Byzantine Empire, began in 330 CE. That’s when Constantine,
the first Christian emperor, moved the capital of the Roman Empire 
to a new city called Constantinople, which he founded on the site of the
ancient Greek city Byzantion. When the Visigoths sacked Rome in 410 and the Empire’s western provinces 
were conquered by barbarians, Constantine’s Eastern capital remained 
the seat of the Roman emperors. There, generations of emperors ruled 
for the next 11 centuries. Sharing continuity with 
the classical Roman Empire gave the Byzantine empire a technological
and artistic advantage over its neighbors, whom Byzantines considered barbarians. In the ninth century, 
visitors from beyond the frontier were astonished 
at the graceful stone arches and domes of the imperial palace in Constantinople. A pair of golden lions flanked 
the imperial throne. A hidden organ would make the lions 
roar as guests fell on their knees. Golden birds
sung from a nearby golden tree. Medieval Roman engineers 
even used hydraulic engines to raise the imperial throne 
high into the air. Other inherited aspects 
of ancient Roman culture could be seen in emperors’ clothing, from traditional military garb to togas, and in the courts, which continued to use Roman law. Working-class Byzantines would’ve also 
had similar lives to their Ancient Roman counterparts; many farmed or plied a specific trade, such as ceramics, leatherworking, fishing, weaving, or manufacturing silk. But, of course, the Byzantine Empire didn’t just rest 
on the laurels of Ancient Rome. Their artists innovated, creating vast 
mosaics and ornate marble carvings. Their architects constructed
numerous churches, one of which, called Hagia Sophia, had a dome so high it was said to be
hanging on a chain from heaven. The Empire was also home to great
intellectuals such as Anna Komnene. As imperial princess in the 12th century, Anna dedicated her life 
to philosophy and history. Her account of her father’s reign
is historians’ foremost source for Byzantine political history 
at the time of the first crusade. Another scholar, Leo the Mathematician, invented a system of beacons that ran the
width of the empire— what’s now Greece and Turkey. Stretching more than 700 kilometers, this system allowed the edge of the Empire
to warn the emperor of invading armies within one hour
of sighting them at the border. But their advances couldn’t 
protect the Empire forever. In 1203, an army of French 
and Venetian Crusaders made a deal with a man 
named Alexios Angelos. Alexios was the son of a deposed emperor, and promised the crusaders vast riches and support to help him retake 
the throne from his uncle. Alexios succeeded, but after a year, the population rebelled and Alexios 
himself was deposed and killed. So Alexios’s unpaid army turned 
their aggression on Constantinople. They lit massive fires, which destroyed countless works of ancient
and medieval art and literature, leaving about one-third 
of the population homeless. The city was reclaimed 50 years later 
by the Roman Emperor Michael Palaiologos, but his restored Empire never regained
all the territory the Crusaders had conquered. Finally, in 1453, Ottoman Emperor Mehmed
the Conqueror captured Constantinople, bringing a conclusive end 
to the Roman Empire. Despite the Ottoman conquest, many Greek-speaking inhabitants 
of the Eastern Mediterranean continued to call themselves Romans 
until the early 21st century. In fact, it wasn’t until the Renaissance that the term “Byzantine Empire” 
was first used. For Western Europeans, the Renaissance was about 
reconnecting with the wisdom of antiquity. And since the existence of a
medieval Roman Empire suggested there were Europeans 
who’d never lost touch with antiquity, Western Europeans wanted to draw 
clear lines between the ages. To better distinguish the classical, 
Latin-speaking, pagan Roman Empire from the medieval, 
Greek-speaking, Christian Roman Empire, scholars renamed 
the latter group Byzantines. And thus, 100 years after it had
fallen, the Byzantine Empire was born.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Alexios Angelos created an alliance with ______ crusaders to depose his uncle.
Options: A. German and Greek, B. French and Venetian, C. Persian and English, D. German and French
Correct Option: B

Question 3: What was the primary reason for the Byzantine Empire's technological and artistic advantage over its neighbors? Options: A. Innovative use of iron and steel, B. Adoption of new architectural styles, C. Continuity with ancient Roman culture, D. Military conquests Correct Option: C
Question 4: Who was the imperial princess who dedicated her life to philosophy and wrote a historical account of her father's reign? Options: A. Anna Komnene, B. Leo the Mathematician, C. Alexios Angelos, D. Michael Palaiologos Correct Option: A
Question 5: Who invented the Byzantine Empire's system of beacons that stretched over 700 kilometers? Options: A. Anna Komnene, B. Leo the Mathematician, C. Alexios Angelos, D. Michael Palaiologos Correct Option: B
Question 6: In 1203, an army of French and Venetian Crusaders made a deal with which man to help him retake the throne from his uncle? Options: A. Alexios Angelos, B. Michael Palaiologos, C. Mehmed the Conqueror, D. Leo the Mathematician Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the name of the church in Constantinople that had a dome so high it was said to be hanging on a chain from heaven? Options: A. Hagia Sophia, B. Byzantine Cathedral, C. Roman Church, D. Imperial Palace Correct Option: A
Question 8: Who conquered Constantinople in 1453, bringing an end to the Roman Empire? Options: A. Mehmed the Conqueror, B. Alexios Angelos, C. Michael Palaiologos, D. Leo the Mathematician Correct Option: A

Question 10: Why did Western Europeans rename the medieval Roman Empire as the Byzantine Empire during the Renaissance? Options: A. To emphasize its connection to ancient Rome, B. To distinguish it from the classical Roman Empire, C. To highlight its Greek-speaking culture, D. To conceal its Christian heritage Correct Option: B

Empire fell in the fifth century CE. But this would’ve come as a great surprise
to the millions of people who lived in the Roman Empire up

to today as the Byzantine Empire, began in 330 CE. That’s when Constantine,

to philosophy and history. Her account of her father’s reign
is historians’ foremost source for Byzantine political history 
at the time of the first crusade. Another scholar, Leo the Mathematician, invented a system of beacons that ran the
width of the empire— what’s now Greece and Turkey. Stretching more than 700 kilometers, this system allowed the edge of the Empire
to warn the emperor of invading armies within one hour
of sighting them at the border. But their advances couldn’t 
protect the Empire forever. In 1203, an army of French 
and Venetian Crusaders made a deal with a man 
named Alexios Angelos. Alexios was the son of a deposed emperor, and promised the crusaders vast riches and support to help him retake 
the throne from his uncle. Alexios succeeded, but after a year, the population rebelled and Alexios 
himself was deposed and killed. So Alexios’s unpaid army turned 
their aggression on Constantinople. They lit massive fires, which destroyed countless works of ancient
and medieval art and literature, leaving about one-third 
of the population homeless. The city was reclaimed 50 years later 
by the Roman Emperor Michael Palaiologos, but his restored Empire never regained
all the territory the Crusaders had conquered. Finally, in 1453, Ottoman Emperor Mehmed

to the Roman Empire. Despite the Ottoman conquest, many Greek-speaking inhabitants 
of the Eastern Mediterranean continued to call themselves Romans 
until the early 21st century. In fact, it wasn’t until the Renaissance that the term “Byzantine Empire” 
was first used. For Western Europeans, the Renaissance was about 
reconnecting with the wisdom of antiquity. And since the existence of a
medieval Roman Empire suggested there were Europeans 
who’d never lost touch with antiquity, Western Europeans wanted to draw 
clear lines between the ages. To better distinguish the classical, 
Latin-speaking, pagan Roman Empire from the medieval, 
Greek-speaking, Christian Roman Empire, scholars renamed 
the latter group Byzantines. And thus, 100 years after it had
fallen, the Byzantine Empire was born.

**Transcript**:
Most history books will tell you the Roman
Empire fell in the fifth century CE. But this would’ve come as a great surprise
to the millions of people who lived in the Roman Empire up
through the Middle Ages. This medieval Roman Empire, which we usually refer 
to today as the Byzantine Empire, began in 330 CE. That’s when Constantine,
the first Christian emperor, moved the capital of the Roman Empire 
to a new city called Constantinople, which he founded on the site of the
ancient Greek city Byzantion. When the Visigoths sacked Rome in 410 and the Empire’s western provinces 
were conquered by barbarians, Constantine’s Eastern capital remained 
the seat of the Roman emperors. There, generations of emperors ruled 
for the next 11 centuries. Sharing continuity with 
the classical Roman Empire gave the Byzantine empire a technological
and artistic advantage over its neighbors, whom Byzantines considered barbarians. In the ninth century, 
visitors from beyond the frontier were astonished 
at the graceful stone arches and domes of the imperial palace in Constantinople. A pair of golden lions flanked 
the imperial throne. A hidden organ would make the lions 
roar as guests fell on their knees. Golden birds
sung from a nearby golden tree. Medieval Roman engineers 
even used hydraulic engines to raise the imperial throne 
high into the air. Other inherited aspects

had similar lives to their Ancient Roman counterparts; many farmed or plied a specific trade, such as ceramics, leatherworking, fishing, weaving, or manufacturing silk. But, of course, the Byzantine Empire didn’t just rest 
on the laurels of Ancient Rome. Their artists innovated, creating vast 
mosaics and ornate marble carvings. Their architects constructed
numerous churches, one of which, called Hagia Sophia, had a dome so high it was said to be

to philosophy and history. Her account of her father’s reign
is historians’ foremost source for Byzantine political history 
at the time of the first crusade. Another scholar, Leo the Mathematician, invented a system of beacons that ran the

to warn the emperor of invading armies within one hour

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A pungent blend of onions, cheese,
and cat urine with hints of... is that…wet goat? Most of us don’t need more than one whiff to identify that generally unpleasant, 
characteristic smell we call body odor. But it’s a surprisingly complex phenomenon influenced by our genetic makeup, 
age, diet, and hygiene. So what is this odor, exactly? Where does it come from? And can we do anything about it? To start, you just need two things 
to produce that familiar scent: your armpit’s own secretions and the bacteria that feed on them. Most people associate 
body odor with sweat, and it’s an important piece of the puzzle. Your body has millions of sweat glands, 
and they come in two major types: eccrine glands are found 
all over your skin and secrete mainly water and salt. Apocrine glands, on the other hand, 
develop at puberty in your armpits and a few other places on your body. The sweat they secrete 
is full of proteins and fats. By themselves, 
these secretions are usually odorless. That’s where bacteria come in. Every square centimeter of our bodies 
is covered with thousands of bacteria. Many microorganisms thrive 
in moist environments, like our armpits. There, you can find about a million 
bacteria per square centimeter, one of the highest concentrations 
anywhere on the skin. Lurking in this throng of microorganisms 
are species of Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others. When these bacteria feed on the proteins 
and fats in apocrine sweat, they turn the odorless compounds into
new ones that can smell very unpleasant. Some of the worst offenders may be 
sulfur-containing chemicals; those give body odor its oniony aroma. Carboxylic acids are in the mix, too, 
adding notes of cheese. These molecules waft up from the armpit 
and can be sucked directly into our noses, where they’re trapped and detected 
by an array of specialized receptors. Those can recognize odor molecules at concentrations 
of less than one in a million. So what determines how strong 
your body odor might be? It depends on the resident microbial
populations in your armpit, and the nutrients that 
your glands provide them with. Your genes help determine 
what compounds you produce, and in what quantity, so everyone has a slightly different set. In fact, a gene variant that virtually 
eliminates body odor is common in people of East Asian descent. Adrenaline increases the ratio 
of apocrine to eccrine sweat, so body odor can be more intense
when you’re nervous. Bacterial composition and concentration 
also varies between individuals and plays a part. Even what you eat can have 
a small effect on how you smell. So how can we deal with body odor? Washing the armpits with soap and water 
helps but won’t remove all the bacteria since many are buried 
in deeper layers of the skin. Deodorants, however, inhibit bacterial 
activity and mask odors at the same time. Antiperspirants work by forming tiny
gel plugs that block sweat glands, drying out the armpits. While we continue to battle body odor, 
scientists are trying to understand it. We don’t know why the brain often interprets these particular 
odors as off-putting. But some researchers have proposed 
that secretions from the armpit could have a positive function, too, like cementing social bonds and providing a means 
of chemical communication. We don’t know yet if that’s the case. For now, body odor seems to be just another smelly part 
of the human condition.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Body odor production requires ______.
Options: A. Eccrine secretion, B. Apocrine secretion, C. Bacteria, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What are the two main types of sweat glands found on human skin? Options: A. Eccrine glands and eccrine glands, B. Apocrine glands and eccrine glands, C. Sweat glands and oil glands, D. Sebaceous glands and eccrine glands Correct Option: B
Question 2: What type of bacteria are commonly found in the armpits, where they feed on proteins and fats in apocrine sweat? Options: A. Staphylococci and Micrococci, B. Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others, C. Bacteria that thrive in dry environments, D. Bacteria that are not found in the human body Correct Option: B
Question 3: What determines the strength of body odor in an individual? Options: A. The type of bacteria present in the armpits, B. The nutrients provided by the glands, C. The resident microbial populations in the armpit, the nutrients provided by the glands, and the individual's genes, D. The presence of sweat Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is a common gene variant that virtually eliminates body odor? Options: A. A gene variant found in people of European descent, B. A gene variant found in people of African descent, C. A gene variant found in people of Latin American descent, D. A gene variant found in people of East Asian descent Correct Option: D
Question 5: What can be used to inhibit bacterial activity and mask odors in the armpits? Options: A. Soap and water, B. Deodorants, C. Antiperspirants, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the primary function of antiperspirants? Options: A. To inhibit bacterial activity and mask odors, B. To form tiny gel plugs that block sweat glands, drying out the armpits, C. To wash away bacteria and odors, D. To reduce the amount of sweat produced Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is a possible positive function of secretions from the armpit? Options: A. Reducing the strength of body odor, B. Increasing the amount of sweat produced, C. Cementing social bonds and providing a means of chemical communication, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the approximate number of bacteria per square centimeter found in the armpits? Options: A. 100, B. 1,000, C. 100,000, D. 1 million Correct Option: D
Question 9: What type of receptors in the nose can recognize odor molecules at concentrations of less than one in a million? Options: A. General olfactory receptors, B. Taste receptors, C. Specialized olfactory receptors, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, why does the brain often interpret the particular odors associated with body odor as off-putting? Options: A. Because the odors are naturally pleasant, B. Because the odors are naturally unpleasant, C. Because the brain has not yet learned to associate the odors with a particular meaning, D. The transcript does not specify why the brain interprets the odors as off-putting Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is a common effect of adrenaline on body odor? Options: A. Reducing the strength of body odor, B. Increasing the amount of sweat produced, C. Increasing the ratio of apocrine to eccrine sweat, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 12: According to the transcript, what is a small effect of diet on body odor? Options: A. Increasing the strength of body odor, B. Reducing the strength of body odor, C. Having no effect on body odor, D. The transcript does not specify the effect of diet on body odor Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is a common way to deal with body odor? Options: A. Using antiperspirants, B. Using deodorants, C. Washing the armpits with soap and water, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 14: According to the transcript, what is a goal of scientists studying body odor? Options: A. To understand why the brain interprets body odor as off-putting, B. To develop new antiperspirants, C. To understand the biology of body odor, D. To eliminate body odor Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A pungent blend of onions, cheese,
and cat urine with hints of... is that…wet goat? Most of us don’t need more than one whiff to identify that generally unpleasant, 
characteristic smell we call body odor. But it’s a surprisingly complex phenomenon influenced by our genetic makeup, 
age, diet, and hygiene. So what is this odor, exactly? Where does it come from? And can we do anything about it? To start, you just need two things 
to produce that familiar scent: your armpit’s own secretions and the bacteria that feed on them. Most people associate 
body odor with sweat, and it’s an important piece of the puzzle. Your body has millions of sweat glands, 
and they come in two major types: eccrine glands are found 
all over your skin and secrete mainly water and salt. Apocrine glands, on the other hand, 
develop at puberty in your armpits and a few other places on your body. The sweat they secrete 
is full of proteins and fats. By themselves, 
these secretions are usually odorless. That’s where bacteria come in. Every square centimeter of our bodies 
is covered with thousands of bacteria. Many microorganisms thrive 
in moist environments, like our armpits. There, you can find about a million 
bacteria per square centimeter, one of the highest concentrations 
anywhere on the skin. Lurking in this throng of microorganisms 
are species of Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others. When these bacteria feed on the proteins 
and fats in apocrine sweat, they turn the odorless compounds into
new ones that can smell very unpleasant. Some of the worst offenders may be 
sulfur-containing chemicals; those give body odor its oniony aroma. Carboxylic acids are in the mix, too, 
adding notes of cheese. These molecules waft up from the armpit 
and can be sucked directly into our noses, where they’re trapped and detected 
by an array of specialized receptors. Those can recognize odor molecules at concentrations 
of less than one in a million. So what determines how strong 
your body odor might be? It depends on the resident microbial
populations in your armpit, and the nutrients that 
your glands provide them with. Your genes help determine 
what compounds you produce, and in what quantity, so everyone has a slightly different set. In fact, a gene variant that virtually 
eliminates body odor is common in people of East Asian descent. Adrenaline increases the ratio 
of apocrine to eccrine sweat, so body odor can be more intense
when you’re nervous. Bacterial composition and concentration 
also varies between individuals and plays a part. Even what you eat can have 
a small effect on how you smell. So how can we deal with body odor? Washing the armpits with soap and water 
helps but won’t remove all the bacteria since many are buried 
in deeper layers of the skin. Deodorants, however, inhibit bacterial 
activity and mask odors at the same time. Antiperspirants work by forming tiny
gel plugs that block sweat glands, drying out the armpits. While we continue to battle body odor, 
scientists are trying to understand it. We don’t know why the brain often interprets these particular 
odors as off-putting. But some researchers have proposed 
that secretions from the armpit could have a positive function, too, like cementing social bonds and providing a means 
of chemical communication. We don’t know yet if that’s the case. For now, body odor seems to be just another smelly part 
of the human condition.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The unpleasant human odor we refer to as “body odor” comes mainly from ______.
Options: A. The groin, B. The feet, C. The whole body, D. The armpits
Correct Option: D

Question 2: What type of bacteria are commonly found in the armpits, where they feed on proteins and fats in apocrine sweat? Options: A. Staphylococci and Micrococci, B. Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others, C. Bacteria that thrive in dry environments, D. Bacteria that are not found in the human body Correct Option: B
Question 3: What determines the strength of body odor in an individual? Options: A. The type of bacteria present in the armpits, B. The nutrients provided by the glands, C. The resident microbial populations in the armpit, the nutrients provided by the glands, and the individual's genes, D. The presence of sweat Correct Option: C

A gene variant found in people of African descent, C. A gene variant found in people of Latin American descent, D. A gene variant found in people of East Asian descent Correct Option: D
Question 5: What can be used to inhibit bacterial activity and mask odors in the armpits? Options: A. Soap and water, B. Deodorants, C. Antiperspirants, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the primary function of antiperspirants? Options: A. To inhibit bacterial activity and mask odors, B. To form tiny gel plugs that block sweat glands, drying out the armpits, C. To wash away bacteria and odors, D. To reduce the amount of sweat produced Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is a possible positive function of secretions from the armpit? Options: A. Reducing the strength of body odor, B. Increasing the amount of sweat produced, C. Cementing social bonds and providing a means of chemical communication, D. None of the above Correct Option: C

Because the odors are naturally unpleasant, C. Because the brain has not yet learned to associate the odors with a particular meaning, D. Question 13: What is a common way to deal with body odor? Options: A. Using antiperspirants, B. Using deodorants, C. Washing the armpits with soap and water, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
A pungent blend of onions, cheese,
and cat urine with hints of... is that…wet goat? Most of us don’t need more than one whiff to identify that generally unpleasant, 
characteristic smell we call body odor. But it’s a surprisingly complex phenomenon influenced by our genetic makeup, 
age, diet, and hygiene. So what is this odor, exactly? Where does it come from? And can we do anything about it? To start, you just need two things 
to produce that familiar scent: your armpit’s own secretions and the bacteria that feed on them. Most people associate 
body odor with sweat, and it’s an important piece of the puzzle. Your body has millions of sweat glands, 
and they come in two major types: eccrine glands are found 
all over your skin and secrete mainly water and salt. Apocrine glands, on the other hand, 
develop at puberty in your armpits and a few other places on your body. The sweat they secrete 
is full of proteins and fats. By themselves, 
these secretions are usually odorless. That’s where bacteria come in. Every square centimeter of our bodies 
is covered with thousands of bacteria. Many microorganisms thrive 
in moist environments, like our armpits. There, you can find about a million 
bacteria per square centimeter, one of the highest concentrations 
anywhere on the skin. Lurking in this throng of microorganisms 
are species of Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others. When these bacteria feed on the proteins 
and fats in apocrine sweat, they turn the odorless compounds into
new ones that can smell very unpleasant. Some of the worst offenders may be 
sulfur-containing chemicals; those give body odor its oniony aroma. Carboxylic acids are in the mix, too, 
adding notes of cheese. These molecules waft up from the armpit 
and can be sucked directly into our noses, where they’re trapped and detected 
by an array of specialized receptors. Those can recognize odor molecules at concentrations 
of less than one in a million. So what determines how strong 
your body odor might be? It depends on the resident microbial
populations in your armpit, and the nutrients that 
your glands provide them with. Your genes help determine 
what compounds you produce, and in what quantity, so everyone has a slightly different set. In fact, a gene variant that virtually 
eliminates body odor is common in people of East Asian descent. Adrenaline increases the ratio 
of apocrine to eccrine sweat, so body odor can be more intense
when you’re nervous. Bacterial composition and concentration 
also varies between individuals and plays a part. Even what you eat can have 
a small effect on how you smell. So how can we deal with body odor? Washing the armpits with soap and water 
helps but won’t remove all the bacteria since many are buried 
in deeper layers of the skin. Deodorants, however, inhibit bacterial 
activity and mask odors at the same time. Antiperspirants work by forming tiny
gel plugs that block sweat glands, drying out the armpits. While we continue to battle body odor, 
scientists are trying to understand it. We don’t know why the brain often interprets these particular 
odors as off-putting. But some researchers have proposed 
that secretions from the armpit could have a positive function, too, like cementing social bonds and providing a means 
of chemical communication. We don’t know yet if that’s the case. For now, body odor seems to be just another smelly part 
of the human condition.

populations in your armpit, and the nutrients that 
your glands provide them with. Your genes help determine 
what compounds you produce, and in what quantity, so everyone has a slightly different set. In fact, a gene variant that virtually 
eliminates body odor is common in people of East Asian descent. Adrenaline increases the ratio 
of apocrine to eccrine sweat, so body odor can be more intense
when you’re nervous. Bacterial composition and concentration 
also varies between individuals and plays a part. Even what you eat can have 
a small effect on how you smell. So how can we deal with body odor? Washing the armpits with soap and water 
helps but won’t remove all the bacteria since many are buried 
in deeper layers of the skin. Deodorants, however, inhibit bacterial 
activity and mask odors at the same time. Antiperspirants work by forming tiny
gel plugs that block sweat glands, drying out the armpits. While we continue to battle body odor, 
scientists are trying to understand it. We don’t know why the brain often interprets these particular 
odors as off-putting. But some researchers have proposed 
that secretions from the armpit could have a positive function, too, like cementing social bonds and providing a means 
of chemical communication. We don’t know yet if that’s the case. For now, body odor seems to be just another smelly part 
of the human condition.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, and Micrococci are ______.
Options: A. Types of sweat glands, B. Types of bacteria, C. Human skin cell lines, D. Types of odors
Correct Option: B

Question 2: What type of bacteria are commonly found in the armpits, where they feed on proteins and fats in apocrine sweat? Options: A. Staphylococci and Micrococci, B. Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others, C. Bacteria that thrive in dry environments, D. Bacteria that are not found in the human body Correct Option: B

Because the odors are naturally unpleasant, C. Because the brain has not yet learned to associate the odors with a particular meaning, D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A pungent blend of onions, cheese,
and cat urine with hints of... is that…wet goat? Most of us don’t need more than one whiff to identify that generally unpleasant, 
characteristic smell we call body odor. But it’s a surprisingly complex phenomenon influenced by our genetic makeup, 
age, diet, and hygiene. So what is this odor, exactly? Where does it come from? And can we do anything about it? To start, you just need two things 
to produce that familiar scent: your armpit’s own secretions and the bacteria that feed on them. Most people associate 
body odor with sweat, and it’s an important piece of the puzzle. Your body has millions of sweat glands, 
and they come in two major types: eccrine glands are found 
all over your skin and secrete mainly water and salt. Apocrine glands, on the other hand, 
develop at puberty in your armpits and a few other places on your body. The sweat they secrete 
is full of proteins and fats. By themselves, 
these secretions are usually odorless. That’s where bacteria come in. Every square centimeter of our bodies 
is covered with thousands of bacteria. Many microorganisms thrive 
in moist environments, like our armpits. There, you can find about a million 
bacteria per square centimeter, one of the highest concentrations 
anywhere on the skin. Lurking in this throng of microorganisms 
are species of Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others. When these bacteria feed on the proteins 
and fats in apocrine sweat, they turn the odorless compounds into
new ones that can smell very unpleasant. Some of the worst offenders may be 
sulfur-containing chemicals; those give body odor its oniony aroma. Carboxylic acids are in the mix, too, 
adding notes of cheese. These molecules waft up from the armpit 
and can be sucked directly into our noses, where they’re trapped and detected 
by an array of specialized receptors. Those can recognize odor molecules at concentrations 
of less than one in a million. So what determines how strong 
your body odor might be? It depends on the resident microbial
populations in your armpit, and the nutrients that 
your glands provide them with. Your genes help determine 
what compounds you produce, and in what quantity, so everyone has a slightly different set. In fact, a gene variant that virtually 
eliminates body odor is common in people of East Asian descent. Adrenaline increases the ratio 
of apocrine to eccrine sweat, so body odor can be more intense
when you’re nervous. Bacterial composition and concentration 
also varies between individuals and plays a part. Even what you eat can have 
a small effect on how you smell. So how can we deal with body odor? Washing the armpits with soap and water 
helps but won’t remove all the bacteria since many are buried 
in deeper layers of the skin. Deodorants, however, inhibit bacterial 
activity and mask odors at the same time. Antiperspirants work by forming tiny
gel plugs that block sweat glands, drying out the armpits. While we continue to battle body odor, 
scientists are trying to understand it. We don’t know why the brain often interprets these particular 
odors as off-putting. But some researchers have proposed 
that secretions from the armpit could have a positive function, too, like cementing social bonds and providing a means 
of chemical communication. We don’t know yet if that’s the case. For now, body odor seems to be just another smelly part 
of the human condition.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Some people have little or no body odor because of their ______.
Options: A. Genetic makeup, B. Sleeping habits, C. Height, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

Question 2: What type of bacteria are commonly found in the armpits, where they feed on proteins and fats in apocrine sweat? Options: A. Staphylococci and Micrococci, B. Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others, C. Bacteria that thrive in dry environments, D. Bacteria that are not found in the human body Correct Option: B
Question 3: What determines the strength of body odor in an individual? Options: A. The type of bacteria present in the armpits, B. The nutrients provided by the glands, C. The resident microbial populations in the armpit, the nutrients provided by the glands, and the individual's genes, D. The presence of sweat Correct Option: C

Increasing the amount of sweat produced, C. Cementing social bonds and providing a means of chemical communication, D. None of the above Correct Option: C

Question 9: What type of receptors in the nose can recognize odor molecules at concentrations of less than one in a million? Options: A. General olfactory receptors, B. Taste receptors, C. Specialized olfactory receptors, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, why does the brain often interpret the particular odors associated with body odor as off-putting? Options: A. Because the odors are naturally pleasant, B. Because the odors are naturally unpleasant, C. Because the brain has not yet learned to associate the odors with a particular meaning, D. The transcript does not specify why the brain interprets the odors as off-putting Correct Option: D

Question 12: According to the transcript, what is a small effect of diet on body odor? Options: A. Increasing the strength of body odor, B. Reducing the strength of body odor, C. Having no effect on body odor, D. The transcript does not specify the effect of diet on body odor Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is a common way to deal with body odor? Options: A. Using antiperspirants, B. Using deodorants, C. Washing the armpits with soap and water, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

A pungent blend of onions, cheese,

and they come in two major types: eccrine glands are found

develop at puberty in your armpits and a few other places on your body. The sweat they secrete 
is full of proteins and fats. By themselves, 
these secretions are usually odorless. That’s where bacteria come in. Every square centimeter of our bodies 
is covered with thousands of bacteria. Many microorganisms thrive 
in moist environments, like our armpits. There, you can find about a million

anywhere on the skin. Lurking in this throng of microorganisms 
are species of Corynebacteria, Staphylococci, Micrococci, and others. When these bacteria feed on the proteins 
and fats in apocrine sweat, they turn the odorless compounds into
new ones that can smell very unpleasant. Some of the worst offenders may be 
sulfur-containing chemicals; those give body odor its oniony aroma. Carboxylic acids are in the mix, too, 
adding notes of cheese. These molecules waft up from the armpit 
and can be sucked directly into our noses, where they’re trapped and detected 
by an array of specialized receptors. Those can recognize odor molecules at concentrations 
of less than one in a million. So what determines how strong 
your body odor might be? It depends on the resident microbial
populations in your armpit, and the nutrients that 
your glands provide them with. Your genes help determine 
what compounds you produce, and in what quantity, so everyone has a slightly different set. In fact, a gene variant that virtually

also varies between individuals and plays a part. Even what you eat can have 
a small effect on how you smell. So how can we deal with body odor? Washing the armpits with soap and water 
helps but won’t remove all the bacteria since many are buried 
in deeper layers of the skin. Deodorants, however, inhibit bacterial 
activity and mask odors at the same time. Antiperspirants work by forming tiny
gel plugs that block sweat glands, drying out the armpits. While we continue to battle body odor, 
scientists are trying to understand it. We don’t know why the brain often interprets these particular 
odors as off-putting. But some researchers have proposed 
that secretions from the armpit could have a positive function, too, like cementing social bonds and providing a means 
of chemical communication. We don’t know yet if that’s the case. For now, body odor seems to be just another smelly part 
of the human condition.

**Transcript**:
curious how good your eyesight is take a look at this image who do you see if you're at a normal viewing distance from the screen and have decent eyesight you should be seeing Albert Einstein however if you see Marilyn Monroe you may want to consider wearing glasses or contacts wearing your glasses right now try taking them off and the image may change or if you're near somebody else ask them what they see the effect can actually be seen by anyone if we change the distance or size of the picture if it's far away you're more like to see Marilyn Monroe as our eyes only pick up the broader Strokes of an image from a distance but as you come closer to the image you see the finer details of Einstein we promise we haven't changed anything digitally in fact pause this video now and try walking away from your computer screen chances are the image will change and at a different distance than your friends because our eyes are all slightly different the further away you can stand and still see Einstein the better your eyes likely are you can achieve the same effect by squinting your eyes to blur the photo so what what's going on well this image is an example of a hybrid image whereby a low spatial frequency of one picture is combined with a high spatial frequency of another but depending on how well you're able to focus or pick up contrast your eye will only pick out certain details up close we're generally able to see fine details like Einstein's mustache and wrinkles but as the distance increases or if your vision is poor and thus creates a more blurred image in the first place your ability to pick up details Fades away instead you only see the general features like the shape of a mouth nose and hair making it seem like Marilyn Monroe love tricking your brain with Illusions we've put together a playlist of our favorite ones that you can watch by clicking the screen don't forget to follow us on Facebook Instagram and Twitter and subscribe for more weekly science videos

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The effect can be seen by anyone when you change the ______ of the picture.
Options: A. Distance, B. Size, C. Neither, D. Both
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the purpose of the image shown in the video? Options: A. To test the viewer's eyesight and vision, B. To demonstrate the effects of aging on the human face, C. To showcase the features of a famous person, D. To illustrate the concept of spatial frequency Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the video, what happens to the image when you wear glasses or contacts? Options: A. It becomes distorted, B. It remains the same, C. It changes from Albert Einstein to Marilyn Monroe, D. It disappears Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the effect of changing the distance from the screen on the image? Options: A. It becomes more detailed, B. It remains the same, C. It changes from Albert Einstein to Marilyn Monroe, D. It becomes less detailed Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why do people see different images at different distances? Options: A. Because of the size of the image, B. Because of the quality of the image, C. Because of the differences in their eyesight, D. Because of the lighting conditions Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the name of the phenomenon demonstrated in the video? Options: A. Optical illusion, B. Spatial frequency illusion, C. Hybrid image illusion, D. Depth perception illusion Correct Option: C
Question 6: How can you achieve the same effect by squinting your eyes? Options: A. By focusing on a point in the distance, B. By looking at the image from a different angle, C. By blurring the photo, D. By covering one eye Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the main idea behind the concept of spatial frequency? Options: A. The ability to see fine details, B. The ability to see general features, C. The combination of low and high spatial frequencies, D. The perception of depth Correct Option: C
Question 8: According to the video, what is the relationship between eyesight and the ability to see details? Options: A. Better eyesight means better ability to see details, B. Poor eyesight means better ability to see details, C. Eyesight has no effect on the ability to see details, D. The ability to see details is independent of eyesight Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the purpose of the video's suggestion to watch a playlist of illusions? Options: A. To demonstrate the effects of aging on the human face, B. To test the viewer's eyesight and vision, C. To showcase the features of a famous person, D. To trick the brain with illusions Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main takeaway from the video about the human brain and perception? Options: A. The brain is capable of seeing only fine details, B. The brain is capable of seeing only general features, C. The brain is capable of perceiving both fine details and general features, D. The brain is not capable of perceiving depth Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is the term for the low spatial frequency of an image? Options: A. High spatial frequency, B. Low spatial frequency, C. Spatial frequency, D. Frequency Correct Option: B
Question 12: What happens to the image when you increase the distance from the screen? Options: A. It becomes more detailed, B. It remains the same, C. It changes from Albert Einstein to Marilyn Monroe, D. It becomes less detailed Correct Option: D
Question 13: According to the video, how can you determine if you have good eyesight? Options: A. By looking at the image from a distance, B. By squinting your eyes, C. By looking at the image from a normal viewing distance, D. By covering one eye Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the relationship between the size of the image and the ability to see details? Options: A. Larger images mean better ability to see details, B. Smaller images mean better ability to see details, C. Image size has no effect on the ability to see details, D. The ability to see details is independent of image size Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
